51277.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
51277.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Patient presents with a complaint of generalized abdominal pain that has persisted for a day. History of Present Illness: Patient describes the pain as sharp in nature, not radiating, and worsening with movement. The patient denies any accompanying nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel movements. Past Medical History: No significant medical history reported. Physical Examination: Vital signs were as follows: BP: 130/85 mmHg, pulse: 90 beats per minute, respirations: 20 per minute, temperature: 98.6 F. On abdominal examination, there was generalized tenderness on palpation. Bowel sounds were present. Assessment: The patient's labs were ordered including CBC, metabolic panel, and liver enzymes. Initial impression is of a nonspecific abdominal pain. Plan: Patient was admitted for further evaluation and management, with the aim of finding the underlying cause. NSAIDs and paracetamol were prescribed for pain control. The patient will also be monitored for changes in symptoms or onset of other symptoms such as nausea and vomiting.
51277.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's symptoms and findings suggest non-specific abdominal pain, which can often be managed effectively in an outpatient setting with close follow-up. I would recommend discharge with outpatient follow-up and labs.
51277.Admission_Note_if_discharged: Given the patient's stable vital signs, absence of significant medical history, non-radiating sharp abdominal pain, and the absence of associated symptoms, this case can be managed on an outpatient basis. The patient can return home and will be scheduled for a telemedicine follow-up appointment. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms or any new symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting. There should be a low threshold for the patient to return to the ER if symptoms intensify or additional concerning symptoms emerge. Outpatient labs will be obtained for further investigation. NSAIDs and paracetamol prescribed for pain control.

175170.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
175170.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Patient presents to the Accident & Emergency Department with intense abdominal pain that has persisted for an approximately 3-4 hours. History of Present Illness: Onset of pain was sudden and severe, localized to the upper abdomen, no radiating pain reported. Patient complains of a feeling of general malaise and weakness. Past Medical History: No previous abdominal surgeries, on medication for blood pressure management. Physical Examination: Vitals stable, abdomen tender to palpation especially in upper quadrants, no visible abnormalities. Assessment: Preliminary impression is of acute abdomen, possible causes could be pancreatitis, gallstones, or peptic ulcer. Plan: Immediate laboratory investigation (including Full Blood Count, Renal Profile, Liver Function Tests, Lipase and Amylase levels, CRP) and abdominal ultrasound ordered. Patient is to be admitted to the hospital for further management and monitoring. Anticipate potential need for endoscopy or CT scan depending on laboratory results. Analgesics given for pain management.
175170.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient has stable vital signs despite experiencing intense abdominal pain. Even though immediate lab tests and imaging have been ordered to identify the exact cause, hospital admission should be avoided unless clearer evidence suggests acute abdomen needing immediate intervention. The cautious approach would involve using outpatient management, while making arrangements for swift hospital admission if the patient's condition exacerbates or lab results indicate an acute issue.
175170.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient is presenting with symptoms of an acute abdomen. The sudden onset and severity of the pain may indicate a serious condition such as pancreatitis, gallstones, or a peptic ulcer that needs immediate treatment. However, manage the condition with proper medication for pain control, dietary restrictions and observation in home-based care, until lab results are received. If symptoms exacerbate or do not improve, the patient should be advised to return to the hospital immediately.

335337.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
335337.Admission_Note: Chief complaint: The patient presented with sudden side weakness, slurred speech, blurred vision, and poor balance. History of present illness: Patient history reveals acute onset of the aforementioned symptoms approximately five hours ago. Prior to symptom onset, the patient was in her usual state of health, suggesting a potential stroke. Past medical history: The patient has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and prior transient ischemic attack. No known allergies. Physical examination: Examination noted facial droop on the left, decreased muscular strength on left side, and sluggish pupil response on left. Vital signs are: BP 150/90mmHg, heart rate 88 bpm, respiratory rate 16, temperature 36.8°C. Preliminary workup: Non-contrast CT head, EKG, CBC, CMP, coagulation profile, and troponin were ordered. Assessment: The clinical picture is highly suggestive of acute cerebrovascular accident. Plan: Admit for further management, neurology consultation, maintain NPO barring swallow examination, initiate aspirin and statin therapy pending imaging results.
335337.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient has potential signs of a cerebrovascular event and needs thorough evaluation and potential intervention. I believe admitting the patient is a medically responsible decision.
335337.Admission_Note_if_discharged: Given the acute onset of the patient's symptoms and the suspicion of a cerebrovascular accident, outpatient care would be risky. Upon discharge, the patient would need to initiate immediate follow-up with a neurologist for further assessment, maintain medication therapy as mentioned in the hospital plan (aspirin and statin therapy), and undergo strict blood pressure control. Any progression of current symptoms or occurrence of new symptoms should warrant immediate hospitalization.

381668.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
381668.Admission_Note:
Chief Complaint: Patient reports persistent fever, sore throat, and fatigue. 

History of Present Illness: Over the past week, the patient’s symptoms have gradually worsened. They have experienced significant fatigue and a high fever accompanied by night sweats. Patient also complained of severe sore throat. 

Past Medical History: Nothing significant to note. 

Physical Examination: Temp of 38.6 C, BP 120/80. Lymphadenopathy noted on neck and armpit. Exudative tonsillitis seen. Spleen palpable. No signs of respiratory distress. 

Assessment: The combination of fatigue, fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy, plus the age group, is suggestive of mononucleosis. 

Plan: Start on supportive care including hydration and pain control. Observe for complications such as spleen complications or secondary strep infection. Consider confirmatory test with Monospot.
381668.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's symptoms are indicative of mononucleosis which is usually self-limiting and can be managed in an outpatient setting unless complications arise. I recommend discharging the patient with advice for rest, hydration and over-the-counter pain medication. A follow-up with primary care is also important to monitor for possible complications.
381668.Admission_Note_if_discharged: If the patient was discharged, they would be advised to continue rest and hydration. Over the counter painkillers can be taken to manage the throat pain and fever. Since the symptoms suggest mononucleosis, the patient should avoid strenuous activities and sports to prevent spleen complications. A follow-up with their primary care provider or local clinic is necessary within the next few days to check on the progression of the illness and if needed, to get a confirmatory test.

405564.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
405564.Admission_Note: Patient presents to the emergency department in the late evening with chief complaints of pervasive and persisting fatigue and general malaise of recent onset. History of present illness reveals that the patient has been experiencing these symptoms for 3 weeks, with no significant respite. Past medical history is unremarkable, no incidence of chronic illness or surgeries. Physical examination shows paleness and lethargy but no abnormalities in cardio-respiratory functions. Blood pressure and heart rate within normal range but patient reports lack of energy or ability to engage in usual activities. Abdominal examination and neurological evaluations show no abnormalities. Lab works including CBC, BMP and TSH ordered to rule out any physiological source of these symptoms. Plan involves admitting the patient for comprehensive medical evaluation and supportive management. Targeted diagnostics planned for probable conditions based on symptoms. The differential diagnosis continues to be expansive given the non-specific nature of symptoms.
405564.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's symptoms while concerning, do not appear to be immediately life-threating or needing rigorous inpatient intervention. It would be preferable to opt for outpatient management whilst further diagnostic procedures are put into place.
405564.Admission_Note_if_discharged: Despite the clear discomfort experienced by the patient, there does not appear to be any immediate risk factor or ailment that requires hospital admission. Further diagnostic tests should be continued in an outpatient setting where they can continue to monitor the patient’s symptoms and come to a more definitive diagnosis. Regular blood tests, close monitoring of the patient's symptoms and consultation continue as outpatient management.

581982.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
581982.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: The patient presents with acute onset of persistent nausea and vomiting accompanied by watery diarrhea. History of Present Illness: The patient reports onset of symptoms approximately 24 hours prior to arrival in the Emergency Department. They experienced increasing severity of symptoms, resulting in compromised oral intake. Past Medical History: The patient has a history of seasonal allergies but no significant other illnesses. Physical Examination: The patient appears dehydrated. Vital signs are stable, BP 125/85, pulse 80, temperature 98.2F. Abdominal exam reveals diffuse tenderness but no rebound or guarding. Rectal exam is normal. Laboratory findings suggests hypokalemia and mild metabolic acidosis, possibly secondary to persistent vomiting and diarrhea. Assessment: Based on the clinical history and examination, the most likely diagnosis is gastroenteritis. Plan: The patient is admitted for fluid replacement and electrolyte correction. Given the dehydration and inability to maintain oral hydration, intravenous fluid resuscitation was initiated along with antiemetic therapy for symptom control. The patient will be monitored closely for resolution of symptoms and improvement in hydration status.
581982.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient presents with gastroenteritis which can generally be managed in the community unless the patient is severely dehydrated or has other serious complications. Given that the patient's vital signs are stable and he only exhibits mild metabolic acidosis, I recommend discharge with instructions for oral rehydration therapy and management of symptoms with prescribed medication. Close follow-up is crucial.
581982.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient's symptoms of gastroenteritis can be managed at home with oral rehydration therapy using a rehydrating solution containing water, sugar, and salts. The patient should be instructed to sip small amounts frequently to prevent further dehydration. Antiemetic and antidiarrheal medications can be prescribed to manage symptoms. The patient can return to the emergency department if symptoms worsen or if they are unable to tolerate oral fluids due to persistent vomiting. Regular follow-up either through telemedicine or outpatient clinic should be arranged.

639536.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
639536.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Patient complains of general weakness and mild pain in the hip area, no visible injuries.  History of Present Illness: Patient states they had a fall in their residence but does not remember the exact event due to confusion. No loss of consciousness reported. Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and arthritis. Physical Examination: Patient alert and oriented but appears weak. Mild tenderness over left hip, nil gross deformity. The rest of the physical exam is unremarkable. The assessment is an elderly patient with an unspecified fall, considering the history. Plan: Admission to the hospital for monitoring, pain management, further investigation into the fall and syncope episode considering the patient's age and symptoms. Necessary tests to be carried out to rule out any underlying issues or injuries including hip x-ray and monitor for any possible post-fall complications.
639536.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient does not exhibit severe symptoms that necessitate immediate in-hospital treatment. Though the patient's confusion around the event of the fall may be concerning, it would be better to arrange for a more suitable care environment such as home health care or a nursing facility, in liaison with their primary care physician, and schedule outpatient diagnostic tests to confirm any suspected diagnoses.
639536.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient has not suffered visible injuries, but due to the fall at their residence, it is advised for them to have regular check-ups to monitor their health condition. Over-the-counter medications can be bought for arthritis and mild pain management. It is also recommended for them to consider shifting to a safer environment with increased accessibility and assistance to prevent further falls. Regular follow-ups concerning hypertension should also be maintained with their regular doctor.

821733.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
821733.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: The patient presents with cough, fever, and difficulty breathing. History of Present Illness: Symptomatology has been escalating over the past week, with increased lethargy and reduced oral intake. No known allergies. Past Medical History: No significant past medical history, no chronic illnesses. Physical Examination: Vital signs are unstable, with respiratory rates of 30 breaths per minute, heart rate of 110bpm, oxygen saturation level of 92% on room air and temperature of 38.5° Celsius. Lung auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds on the right lower lobe. Assessment: Symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with lower respiratory tract infection, likely bacterial pneumonia. Initial laboratory tests, including complete blood count, show an increase in white blood cell count. Chest radiograph shows consolidation in the right lower lobe, supportive of the diagnosis. Plan: Begin empiric antibiotics and maintain fluid and electrolyte balance. Supplemental oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation greater than 94%. Close monitoring of vital signs and re-evaluation in 24 hours. If respiratory distress persists, consult pediatric intensive care team. Admission to the pediatric ward for further management and care.
821733.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's vital signs are unstable, their symptomatology has been escalating significantly and they present with likely bacterial pneumonia. Given the current state of the patient, in my opinion, this warrants a period of inpatient monitoring and treatment.
821733.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient can continue antibiotics treatment at home, and maintain hydration. Twice daily temperature checks should be done and if the fever persists for more than 48 hours, the patient should be brought back to the hospital. A pulse oximeter should be used at home to monitor oxygen saturation levels and if they drop below 94%, the patient should be brought back to the emergency department immediately. Follow-up with the primary care provider in 1 week, or sooner if symptoms get worse,

823847.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
823847.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Confusion, forgetfulness and intermittent agitation. History of Present Illness: Patient, an 85+ year old with known medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes, presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of increasing confusion over the past week. Past Medical History: Hypertension, Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. Physical Examination: Appearance well kempt but patient appeared confused. Speech was fluent but content was disoriented. Vital signs: BP 145/90mmHg, HR 90bpm, Temp 98°F, SpO2 96% on room air. Cardiovascular exam revealed regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, rubs or gallops. Lungs were clear to auscultation. Assessment: The patient's presentation suggests an acute exacerbation of unspecified dementia. Plan: Admitted for further evaluation and management of dementia. Workup to include comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, urinalysis, chest radiography. Mental status monitoring and neurology consult for evaluation of dementia status.
823847.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's presentation suggests a non-emergency worsening of symptoms associated with his known condition. Since his vitals are stable and there are no signs of acute medical distress, he could be safely handled in an outpatient setting under the supervision of a neurologist and his primary care doctor.
823847.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient's dementia seems to be worsening. If discharged, ensure follow-up with his primary care doctor and schedule an appointment with a neurologist. Monitor his mental status closely. Contact a social worker to ensure that the patient's care environment is safe and that there's someone who can look after him at all times. If symptoms get worse, the patient should return to the hospital immediately.

856108.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
856108.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Patient presents with symptoms of respiratory distress, productive cough, and fever. History of Present Illness : The 70-year-old patient's symptoms started approximately 4 days ago with a dry cough and mild fever, gradually worsening to the current state. Past Medical History includes hypertension and coronary artery disease. Physical Examination reveals crackles on lung auscultation, elevated temperature (38.8°C), increased respiratory rate, and lower O2 saturation level (89%). Assessment: Given the patient's age, symptoms, and physical exam findings, the presentation coincides with the possibility of pneumonia. Laboratory findings also reveal high white blood cell count suggesting an ongoing infection. Relevance is seen with the ICD10 code XVIII, indicative of Symptoms, signs, and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings. Plan: The patient is admitted for further evaluation and treatment. The immediate plan includes chest x-ray, blood and sputum cultures, IV antibiotics, oxygen supplementation, monitoring vital signs, and supportive management.
856108.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside the hospital setting. In this case, the patient presents with clear signs of pneumonia and given their age and past medical history, the risk for severe pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome is high. I agree with your decision to admit the patient.
856108.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient can be managed on oral antibiotics along with regular monitoring of their temperature, blood pressure, oxygen saturation level, and other vitals. They should be advised to rest, maintain hydration, and seek immediate medical help if their symptoms worsen. They will require daily telehealth check-ups with their primary care provider and immediate referral to the emergency department if their condition deteriorates.

918261.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
918261.Admission_Note: CHIEF COMPLAINT: Cough and fever. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: A 10 year old patient arrived at the ED complaining of cough and fever for the past 3 days. Cough is productive of yellow sputum. Fever peaks at 38.4°C, intermittent, relieved temporarily by paracetamol. No other accompanying symptoms like shortness of breath or chest pain. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: No known allergies. Immunizations are up-to-date. No previous hospitalizations. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Patient appears febrile but not in distress. CR: 100 bpm, RR: 24 cpm, BP: 100/60 mmHg, Temp: 38.2°C. Chest: Rhonchi heard over both lungs. ASSESSMENT: Acute bronchitis. PLAN: Admission for intravenous antibiotics, supportive treatment for fever and cough, and close monitoring of vitals. Re-evaluate condition after 48 hours for possible discharge.
918261.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient has regular symptoms of acute bronchitis and there are no other accompanying symptoms like shortness of breath or chest pain. Therefore, the condition can be safely managed in an outpatient setting with oral antibiotics instead of intravenous, and symptomatic treatment for fever and cough.
918261.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient is diagnosed with acute bronchitis with regular symptoms and no known allergies or previous hospitalizations. If discharged, a course of oral antibiotics can be prescribed, and the symptoms can be managed with paracetamol and regular rest. Fever and cough should be monitored, and the patient should be advised to return to the hospital if there's no improvement or if symptoms worsen. A follow-up appointment with the primary care physician should be arranged to monitor the recovery.

1703587.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
1703587.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Patient aged above 85 came to the A&E with altered consciousness and weakness, no known trauma. History of Present Illness: Patient has a history of initial confusion progressing into altered consciousness over last couple of hours, associated with generalized weakness. No history of fever or cough, though patient was unable to provide extensive history due to decreased alertness. Past Medical History: Unknown at this moment due to patient's altered state. Physical Examination: Confused, appears older than stated age. Vitals stable, afebrile. Lab: Initial test results show abnormal liver enzymes, kidney function tests, and electrolyte imbalances. Assessment: The patient presents with an altered level of consciousness which could be secondary to several factors including infection, medication side effects, metabolic imbalances or an underlying neurological condition. Further diagnostic tests are necessary to narrow down and identify the cause. Plan: Administer fluids, obtain head CT, blood culture, urinalysis and toxicology panel. Consultation requested from neurology for further management. Multidisciplinary team care has been commenced to cater to potential complex needs of the patient.
1703587.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient presented unspecific symptoms, and while they point towards a potentially serious condition, there was no immediate threat to the patient's life. The patient's vitals were stable and the proposed plan of action—running tests, plus the neuro consultation—can be arranged for outpatient care. Constant monitoring to enable rapid revision of the plan if needed should be recommended.
1703587.Admission_Note_if_discharged: Dear Patient, your condition presented several unspecific symptoms, such as altered consciousness and weakness. In such situations, it's crucial to further investigate. However, based on your stable vital signs and absence of acute symptoms, we're planning on discharging you with close outpatient follow-up. We've arranged for initial investigations like blood culture, urinalysis, a head CT, and toxicology panel to be done in the outpatient setting. Home health care will help monitoring your condition daily. You’ll also have a neurology appointment for further assessment. Please seek immediate medical care if the symptoms worsen or new ones occur.

2106639.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
2106639.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Patient reports general malaise, fever, and a persistent, non-productive cough. History of Present Illness: Symptoms started 5-6 days ago and have progressively worsened. The patient denies chest pain but reports shortness of breath. Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and is a former smoker. Physical Examination: Patient appears fatigued; Vital signs are within normal limits except for elevated body temperature at 38.4 C. Assessment: Given the patient's presenting symptoms and ICD10 chapter XVIII code, a viral infection is suspected. Plan: Initial plan includes laboratory testing for infection markers and chest X-ray. If the tests confirm viral infection, the treatment plan will include hydration, antipyretic for fever control, and plenty of rest. Patient will be monitored closely for any changes in condition or development of complications during their 2-day hospital stay. Education will be provided on signs of worsening condition where they should seek immediate medical attention.
2106639.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient presents with symptoms of a possible viral infection, which in most cases is manageable at home with simple supportive measures. There are no current findings warranting immediate inpatient care such as abnormal vitals or resistance to antipyretic treatment. The plan for aggressive monitoring can be accomplished on an outpatient basis. Furthermore, admitting such a patient poses a risk of unnecessary exposure to other hospital pathogens. This could be counterintuitive to the patient's recovery progress. I would recommend reconsideration with these factors in mind.
2106639.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient's condition, while concerning, is possibly due to a viral infection, which is typically managed at home. Recommendations for outpatient care include rest, hydration, use of antipyretics for fever control, and monitoring of symptoms. The patient should return to the ER or contact their primary care physician if their condition worsens or if they develop chest pain, severe difficulty breathing, or other concerning symptoms. A follow-up with their primary care doctor in two days to reassess their condition is advised.

2294140.Title: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified
2294140.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Confusion, lethargy, and memory issues. History of Present Illness: An 85-year-old patient, presenting with worsening confusion, sluggishness and recurring memory problems over the past two weeks. Past Medical History: Hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and previous episodes of similar complaints. Physical Examination: Alert but disoriented in place and time, normal vital signs with BP 140/80, pulse 80, respirations 18, temperature 37C, O2 saturation 98% on room air. Assessment: The patient's state, along with known history, and age-factor, indicates likely onset of an unspecified dementia, although further tests are required to rule out other conditions. There are no apparent signs of injury or pain reported by the patient. Plan: Admit for observation and additional diagnostic testing, including a cognitive assessment, complete blood count, and brain imaging. Geriatric consultation is requested. Consider starting on donepezil pending further investigation results.
2294140.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's condition, while serious, does not appear to pose an immediate health threat that requires hospitalization. It might be appropriate to consider managing the patient's symptoms with close outpatient follow-up and scheduled diagnostic testing. However, your comprehensive evaluation is commendable.
2294140.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient's condition, while concerning, does not seem to pose an immediate health threat and could be managed with close observation and follow-ups in an outpatient setting. Follow-up appointments will include the scheduled diagnostic tests and consultations. In the event of significant cognitive decline or if the patient's condition worsens, he should be brought back to the emergency department.

2525492.Title: Diseases of the circulatory system
2525492.Admission_Note:
Chief Complaint: Chest Pain, Shortness of Breath.
History of Present Illness: Patient presents with severe central chest pain, radiating to the arms. Accompanied by palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath. Onset was sudden, occurring while the patient was at rest. No relief with rest or nitroglycerin.
Past Medical History: No history of heart disease, diabetes or hypertension. Non-smoker, occasional alcohol. No family history of cardiovascular disease.
Physical Examination: Visual distress, diaphoresis noted. BP 150/90 mmHg, pulse 110 bpm, irregular. Cardiac examination reveals S4 gallop. ECG shows ST elevation.
Assessment: Symptoms, ECG changes indicative of Acute Myocardial Infarction.
Plan: Admit to cardiac care unit immediately. Administer aspirin, clopidogrel, nitroglycerin, and morphine as needed for pain. Schedule for cardiac catheterization. Begin beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and statins following stabilization. Education on lifestyle changes.
2525492.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient exhibits symptoms strongly suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction, a medical emergency that requires immediate in-hospital care. Therefore, I agree with your decision to admit the patient to the cardiac care unit.
2525492.Admission_Note_if_discharged: Given the patient's presentation of sudden onset severe chest pain and ECG changes indicative of Acute Myocardial Infarction, emergency hospitalization and immediate cardiac care is required. This case cannot be managed safely and effectively on an outpatient basis. Hence, a discharge note at this time would not apply.

2680041.Title: Diseases of the circulatory system
2680041.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Patient presented at A&E with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and shortness of breath. History of Present Illness: Symptoms started approximately 8 hours prior to arrival. Patient self-administered nitroglycerin, which temporarily relieves symptoms but pain returns. Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, treated with medication. No previous cardiac events noted. Physical Examination: Vital signs revealed BP of 150/90 mmHg, HR of 110 bpm, RR of 22 breaths/min, Temp of 37°C. Examination showed diaphoresis, anxious appearance, distant heart sounds, crackles at the lung bases. Assessment: Based on the presentation, history, and physical examination, suspecting myocardial infarction. Plan: Admit the patient to the Cardiac Care Unit (CCU) for further management. Prepare for immediate EKG and lab-work to confirm the diagnosis. Pending results, initiate treatment with antiplatelet, anticoagulant, and if necessary, thrombolytic therapy.
2680041.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient presents severe symptoms in conjunction with medical history that suggest a high likelihood of a myocardial infarction. To ensure the patient's safety and potentially save their life, hospital admission is warranted for immediate testing, monitoring and treatment.
2680041.Admission_Note_if_discharged: With symptoms and medical history presented, if discharged, the patient needs to be closely monitored in an outpatient care. Arrange for regular visits to ensure adequate care. It is crucial to continue with their current medication, nitroglycerin to manage chest pain and hypertension. Also, outpatient care would require lifestyle modifications such as a heart-healthy diet, regular exercise, avoiding tobacco and alcohol, and stress management. This patient must be aware of the symptoms of a heart attack and should seek immediate medical attention if these symptoms occur.

3405031.Title: Diseases of the circulatory system
3405031.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of angina, including chest tightness and shortness of breath. History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing the aforementioned symptoms intermittently for the past two weeks, with a recent increase in severity that prompted the hospital visit. Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, both of which are currently managed by medication. A recent lipid panel showed elevated low-density lipoprotein levels. Physical Examination: The patient appears in mild distress. Vital signs are stable but BP is elevated at 150/95. Auscultation reveals a regular rhythm with no murmurs. Assessment: The patient's presentation, history, and physical examination findings are indicative of ischemic heart disease. Plan: Admit the patient for monitoring, medication adjustment, and further diagnostic testing to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment decisions.
3405031.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient shows signs of a serious and potentially life-threatening condition that might necessitate immediate intervention. Considering this alongside the fact that their blood pressure is elevated, I agree with your decision to admit.
3405031.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient's symptoms and history are concerning for ischemic heart disease. If discharged, the patient should be instructed to strictly adhere to their current medication regimen and to consult their primary care provider immediately. A follow-up appointment with Cardiology should be arranged within the next 2-3 days for further evaluation, possible medication adjustment and diagnostic testing.

3441669.Title: Diseases of the circulatory system
3441669.Admission_Note:
Chief Complaint: The patient presents with palpitations, irregular pulse, and shortness of breath. History of Present Illness: The patient states that the symptoms began a few hours ago while at home and have progressively worsened, precipitating their visit to the hospital.

Past Medical History: The patient has a history of untreated hypertension but no other known cardiac diseases. Physical Examination: The patient appears mildly distress, heart rate is irregularly irregular, and there is a slight elevation in blood pressure. No visible chronic signs are noted in the cardiovascular system examination.

Assessment: Given the age of the patient, presentation, the initial exam, and the fact that atrial fibrillation is the most common heart condition in this age group, the patient is most likely suffering from atrial fibrillation and needs immediate treatment.

Plan: Initiate anticoagulation and rate control as per the guidelines for atrial fibrillation. Echocardiogram and cardiac monitoring to be scheduled while inpatient. The patient will be educated about the condition, lifestyle modifications, and medication adherence will be emphasized.
3441669.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. 4132525.Title: Diseases of the respiratory system

6423096.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Dysuria, frequent urination. History of Present Illness: The patient presents with urinary frequency and dysuria over the past week. No known allergies. Past Medical History: Hypertension managed with lifestyle modifications. No known history of genitourinary diseases. Physical Examination: Vital signs stable. Plethora noted. Superficial abdominal palpation shows mild tenderness over lower abdomen; no signs of peritoneal irritation. Assessment: A review of the symptoms suggests urinary tract infection. The observed signs and patient statements align with this diagnosis. The patient's history does not suggest previous genitourinary issues, making the current condition likely an isolated incident rather than a chronic issue. Plan: Urinalysis and culture to confirm UTI. If the results confirm our suspicion, initiate empirical antibiotics therapy.
6423096.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's observed signs, symptoms, and medical history suggest a straightforward UTI. These cases are usually successfully managed with oral antibiotics in an outpatient setting. As such, I would recommend revisiting the decision to admit.
6423096.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient should be discharged with a course of oral antibiotics for the treatment of a urinary tract infection (UTI). Over the counter pain relief may be utilized for symptomatic relief from dysuria. The patient should be informed to consume plenty of fluids and to return for reassessment if symptoms worsen, persist beyond 2-3 days, or new symptoms develop. A urinalysis and culture will be carried out in outpatient and if the results require, changes in the treatment plan can be done later.

6567916.Title: Injury, poisoning and certain other consequences of external causes
6567916.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Fall with consequent severe pain in the hip region. History of Present Illness: The patient is an 85+ year old who presents with acute hip pain following a fall at home today. No history of similar events.  Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension, managed with medications. Physical Examination: Alert and oriented x3, appears uncomfortable. Hip examination reveals significant tenderness, pain with passive/active movement, inability to bear weight. Other physical evaluations unremarkable. Vital signs: Blood pressure - [maintained], Pulse - [normal rate], Respiratory rate - [within normal limit]. Assessment: Acute hip pain with history of fall suggestive of possibility of hip fracture. Plan: Will obtain hip x-ray for further assessment, analgesics for pain and orthopedic consult if required. Patient requires admission under orthopaedics for management and nursing care. Given the expected duration of stay, the patient will be receiving multiple assessments and progress will be closely monitored.
6567916.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient, due to their signs of potential hip fracture and inability to bear weight, does indeed require hospital care. The decision for admission under orthopaedics for management and nursing care aligns with the conditions of the patient.
6567916.Admission_Note_if_discharged: Although the patient has experienced a fall and is presenting acute hip pain, the current considerations point towards the necessity of hospital admission. However, should we choose to manage the patient as an outpatient, the implementation of pain medications and regular, supervised home-care checks should be in place. We could arrange an orthopaic consultation via telemedicine and, unless the condition worsens, follow-up X-rays can be scheduled at an appropriate time.

7094679.Title: Injury, poisoning and certain other consequences of external causes
7094679.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Patient presents with severe pain and swelling in multiple areas of the body with visible wounds and abrasions. History of Present Illness: The patient was involved in a road traffic accident, but the details are unclear. Past Medical History: The patient has no significant past medical history. Physical Examination: Patient is alert but in pain. Multiple contusions and lacerations visible on the body, with localized swelling in the right arm and leg. No apparent head or neck injuries. Pulse: 100 BPM, BP: 130/85 mmHg, Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute, Oxygen saturation: 97% on room air. Assessment: The patient will need immediate attention for their wounds and a thorough evaluation for potential fractures or internal injuries. Plan: Immediate wound cleaning and dressing. Pain management. X-rays for the right arm and leg. CT scan for internal injuries. Observation over the next 72 hours for any complications.
7094679.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient presents with multiple contusions and lacerations, but no apparent head or neck injuries. Given the trauma and severity of the pain, I agree that admission for immediate wound care, potential fracture evaluation, and monitoring for complications is appropriate. However, future training should include consideration of using resources like community care, when hospital is at capacity.
7094679.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient could be managed as an outpatient with regular wound care, pain management, and follow-up radiology as needed. We would provide a plan for self-care and wound management, including signs of infection to watch for. They would return to emergency if pain worsens or signs of possible fracture or internal injury develop such as worsening swelling, bruising, pain or inability to use a limb. Regular check-ups in the outpatient clinic will be scheduled.

7281268.Title: Injury, poisoning and certain other consequences of external causes
7281268.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: The patient presented in the A&E department with intense pain, bleeding, and visible bone fragments in the affected limb. History of Present Illness: The patient apparently sustained the injury in a fall at home. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Physical Examination: Significant deformity of affected limb, intense swelling, visible bone fragments, and compromised peripheral circulation. Vital signs: BP 130/80 mmHg, HR 95 bpm, Resp 18 breaths/min, Temp 98.2 F. Assessment: Significant compound fracture requiring immediate treatment and subsequent hospitalization. Plan: Immediate surgical repair of the fracture followed by a post-op recovery period with ongoing pain management and occupation therapy. Possible complications such as infection or inadequate bone healing to be monitored vigilantly.
7281268.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's condition of a compound fracture with compromised peripheral circulation certainly requires inpatient care. The patient requires immediate surgical intervention and being an instance of severe trauma, the potential for complications is significant. It's clear that your decision to admit was absolutely correct, and not doing so would've posed a huge risk to the patient's health.
7281268.Admission_Note_if_discharged: In case of discharge, the patient would need to attend regular follow-ups at our fracture clinic, ensuring that proper healing is taking place and managing pain effectively. Despite the fact that we can't avoid hospital admission because the fracture requires surgery, in a hypothetical scenario where immediate surgery was not needed, we could possibly manage the patient with cast immobilization, painkillers, and strict non-weight bearing instructions. Any signs of infection, compartment syndrome, or other concerns would need to be reported immediately for hospital evaluation.

7445581.Title: Injury, poisoning and certain other consequences of external causes
7445581.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Severe pain in right leg with apparent deformation. History of Present Illness: Patient presented in the ED after a fall resulting in an injury to the right leg. Describes the pain as 9/10, stabbing, and constant. Unable to bear weight on the leg. Past Medical History: None of relevance disclosed. Physical Examination: Notable for deformity and tenderness of the right thigh, inability to move right leg. No open wounds, pulses palpable. Assessment: Suspected femur fracture based on clinical manifestation. Plan: Pain management, orthopedic consultation. Immediate radiographic imaging to confirm the diagnosis.
7445581.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient has a likely fracture of the femur and is in severe pain, consistent with your assessment. This requires immediate inpatient orthopedic intervention and likely surgery. Thus, I agree with your decision to admit the patient.
7445581.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient should be managed with pain relief medication and undergo outpatient orthopedic rehabilitation after the immediate setting of the fracture and pain management, once stable they can be discharged with a referral to a local orthopedic clinic for follow-up and physical therapy.

8585912.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
8585912.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Severe abdominal pain. History of Present Illness: The patient presented with a sudden onset of severe, crampy abdominal pain centered in the right upper quadrant and radiating to the back, along with vomiting. The pain has been worsening over the last 48 hours. Past Medical History: Mild obesity, no known surgical interventions. Physical Examination: Right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness; vital signs were slightly elevated with BP 140/90, HR 100, Temp 38.2C. Lab results showed elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Assessment: The patient's symptoms, physical examination, and lab results suggest a diagnosis of gallstones. Plan: Admit the patient for further evaluation and treatment. The patient will need to undergo an ultrasound of the abdomen to confirm the presence of gallstones. If confirmed, the patient might require surgical intervention. Prescribe pain management and possible antibiotics pending further investigation.
8585912.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's clinical presentation does not necessarily require immediate hospitalization. Pain management can be accomplished at home while awaiting an outpatient ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis. If the diagnosis is confirmed, we can then consider whether an inpatient procedure or outpatient management is most appropriate based on the severity of the disease, size and number of gallstones, and patient's overall health status.
8585912.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient's symptoms suggest a diagnosis of gallstones, a condition that, while painful, can often be managed in an outpatient setting pending confirmation of the diagnosis. If discharged, the patient should seek immediate care if the pain worsens or if symptoms such as fever, vomiting, or yellowing of the eyes or skin develop, which could be signs of complications such as infection or jaundice. The patient should be scheduled for an outpatient ultrasound in 24 to 48 hours and referred to a gastroenterologist for follow-up. Pain management should be prescribed to manage symptoms in the interim. This prevents an unnecessary hospital admission which might increase the risk of healthcare-associated infections without necessarily improving the patient's outcomes.

8610815.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
8610815.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Recurrent abdominal discomfort. History of Present Illness: A 70yo patient presents with a history of intermittent, dull abdominal discomfort, fatigue and recent onset jaundice over the past month. No fever, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. Past Medical History: Known hypertensive and occasional alcohol intake, adherence to prescribed medication is low. Physical Examination: Abdomen is tender on palpation in right upper quadrant with hepatomegaly. Icteric sclera observed. No evidence of ascites or peripheral edema. Important Vital Signs: BP- 160/90 mm Hg, Pulse- 92/min, Respiratory rate- 18/min, Temp- 98.2°F Assessment: Likely Liver Cirrhosis. Patient's symptoms, history of hypertension, alcohol use and physical findings suggestive of the same. Plan: Admit patient under the care of Gastroenterology. Need complete blood counts, liver function tests, Coagulation profile, ultrasound abdomen and endoscopy. Management will be symptomatic and specific depending upon reports. Refrain from alcohol. Close monitoring necessary due to patient's age.
8610815.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient could have been safely managed in an outpatient setting with a regular follow-up, comprehensive test, lifestyle modification and specialist referral.
8610815.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient can be discharged and closely monitored in an outpatient setting. The patient will need complete blood counts, liver function tests, coagulation profile and an ultrasound of the abdomen. The patient is advised to refrain from alcohol and manage his hypertension actively. Regular follow-ups and a referral will be arranged for a Gastro consultation as this is suggestive of Liver Cirrhosis.

8706907.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
8706907.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Severe abdominal pain mainly in the lower right abdomen with accompanying nausea. History of Present Illness: Patient reports the pain started 10 hours ago and has been gradually getting worse. No recent history of similar pain episodes. Past Medical History: No relevant past medical history. Physical Examination: Patient's vital signs show tachycardia and fever. Abdomen is tender to palpation in the right iliac fossa which intensifies on rebound. Assessment: Based on the history and physical exam, acute appendicitis is suspected. Plan: Immediate surgical consultation is warranted. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotic prophylaxis will be initiated. Abdominal Imaging (CT or Ultrasound) will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis where possible.
8706907.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient is suspected to have acute appendicitis, needing immediate surgical consultation. Delaying hospital admission could result in severe complications. I agree with your decision to admit the patient. Well done on cueing in on the signs and performing a thorough examination.
8706907.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient is suspected of having acute appendicitis which is a surgical emergency. Delaying hospital admission could result in severe complications including rupture and peritonitis. Therefore, discharging the patient is not recommended. If the patient were to be discharged, an immediate revisit to the hospital would be required at the earliest signs of worsening symptoms.

9047569.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
9047569.Admission_Note:
Chief Complaint: The patient presents with an onset of abdominal discomfort and bloating, with intermittent episodes of sharp pain, primarily in the left lower quadrant. Accompanying symptoms include episodes of diarrhea and constipation, accompanied by low-grade fever.

History of Present Illness: Symptom onset was about a week ago. The discomfort has gradually worsened, punctuated by episodes of intense pain. A decrease in appetite has been observed, but no vomiting.

Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and was previously diagnosed with diverticulosis. No prior surgical history.

Physical Examination: Patient is in obvious discomfort. Lower abdominal tenderness present, primarily to the lower left. Bowel sounds somewhat decreased. No distension observed.

Assessment: Symptoms, medical history, and physical examination findings appear consistent with an acute episode of diverticulitis. However, gastrointestinal malignancy cannot be ruled out given the patient’s age group.

Plan: Admitting the patient for medical management and further evaluation, including CT scanning, bacterial culture, complete blood count, & inflammatory markers. Initial management to include bowel rest, IV fluids, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
9047569.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient presents with an acute episode of diverticulitis which can initially be managed in out-patient settings with oral antibiotics, dietary modification, and close monitoring. Admission might be necessary if the condition doesn't improve or if it worsens.
9047569.Admission_Note_if_discharged: If discharged, the patient would be managed with oral antibiotics for the acute diverticulitis, pain management, and recommendations to continue a high fiber diet and increase their fluid intake. Regular follow-ups with primary care physician and gastroenterologist would be needed to monitor condition. Furthermore, colonoscopy might be advisable after the episode of diverticulitis has resolved to screen for possible malignancies.

9247667.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
9247667.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: The patient presents with stomach pain, nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea. History of Present Illness: Over the last 48 hours, the patient has experienced increasing abdominal discomfort, watery stools, occasional bouts of vomiting, and loss of appetite. No prior incidents reported. Past Medical History: No significant past medical history. Non-smoker and occasional alcohol consumer. Physical Examination: Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the lower quadrants with increased bowel sounds. Vital signs within normal limits. Assessment: Symptoms are consistent with gastroenteritis. Plan: Admit for hydration, symptom management, and further diagnostic workup. Consider initiating antibiotic therapy based on stool culture results. Monitor vital signs closely. Educate patient on the importance of hand hygiene to prevent spread of disease.
9247667.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient's symptoms suggest a mild case of gastroenteritis, which can be adequately managed in the community with oral rehydration therapy and over-the-counter symptom relief. There is no need for immediate in-hospital treatment unless the patient's condition significantly deteriorates or fails to respond to treatment. Always consider the burden on the hospital system when making admission decisions.
9247667.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The symptoms presented by the patient suggest a case of gastroenteritis, which is typically non-severe and can be managed in the community rather than in a hospital setting. The treatment plan would be oral rehydration therapy, rest, maintaining adequate nutrition and symptom management with OTC medications. A stool sample should be sent to the lab for bacteria and other infectious agents. Should symptoms significantly worsen or fail to improve, the patient should be admitted.

9345470.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
9345470.Admission_Note:
Chief Complaint: Severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and inability to pass gas or stools. 

History of Present Illness: The patient presents with progressive symptoms over the last week, accompanied by slight fever. He reports previous similar but minor discomforts which self-resolved after a short period. 

Past Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of diverticulitis, well-managed with dietary modification, and no previous surgical interventions. No known drug allergies. 

Physical Examination: His abdomen is distended, with mixed bowel sounds; tenderness is localized in the lower left quadrant. No palpable masses were detected. 

Assessment: Given the patient's history, physical exam findings, and the ICD-10 chapter of Diseases of the digestive system, an intestinal obstruction is suspected. This diagnosis aligns with his symptomology and past history and would be significant enough to warrant his 8-day hospital stay. 

Plan: Admit the patient, begin intravenous fluid rehydration, and cease oral intake. Order a CT scan of the abdomen to confirm obstruction. Consultation with a gastrointestinal surgeon is needed if conservative management fails or if the patient's condition deteriorates.
9345470.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient has a history of diverticulitis, and the current symptoms are severe and progressive, with signs suggesting a possible intestinal obstruction. I concur with your decision to admit the patient, as these symptoms require immediate treatment and cannot be easily managed in the community. Hesitation here may lead to preventable complications.
9345470.Admission_Note_if_discharged: If the patient were to be discharged instead of admitted, an abdominal X-ray series would be performed, and if required, an urgent outpatient CT scan can be organized. The patient would be advised to follow a clear liquid diet in addition to their usual dietary modifications for diverticulitis and to maintain hydration. Close follow-up would be arranged with their primary care provider and if symptoms worsen, they should return to the emergency department immediately.

9354684.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
9354684.Admission_Note: The patient is an 18-24-year-old who arrived at the A&E department of our hospital. Chief complaint at the time of admission is severe abdominal pain which started around 12 hours ago, mostly localized around the right lower quadrant which is consistent with McBurney's point tenderness. The pain is described as continuous, gradually worsening, rated as 8 on a scale of 0-10. Accompanied by symptoms of nausea and vomiting. The patient denies any change in bowel habits, urinary symptoms, or other systemic symptoms. Past medical history is unremarkable. On examination, the patient appears in distress due to pain, vitals stable with mild tachycardia, abdominal examination reveals rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa. Preliminary labs show leucocytosis with a shift to the left. Based on the clinical presentation, an urgent surgical consultation is made with a preliminary diagnosis of acute appendicitis. The plan is to manage the patient with IV hydration, antibiotics, analgesics, and pending surgical evaluation for possible appendectomy.
9354684.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. However, in this case, the patient presents with clear signs of suspected acute appendicitis, characterized by severe abdominal pain localizing to the right lower quadrant, nausea, vomiting, and significant distress. Acute appendicitis requires timely intervention via surgical consultation and possible appendectomy to prevent serious complications, such as perforation or abscess formation. Discharging this patient might risk compromising their safety.
9354684.Admission_Note_if_discharged: If the patient were to be discharged, we should advise them to return to the hospital promptly if their pain continues or worsens. They should also return if they experience any new symptoms such as fever, vomiting, diarrhoea or blood in their stool. An appropriate analgesic for pain and anti-emetic for nausea should be prescribed. Also, recommend close follow-up with their primary care physician for monitoring and revaluation.

9387761.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
9387761.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: Patient presents with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and noticeable blood in their vomit. History of Present Illness: The patient reports that symptoms have been escalating over the past few days with increasing discomfort and weakness. Past Medical History: Patient reports sporadic episodes of similar, but less severe, symptoms in the past. No known allergies or medical surgeries in their medical history. Physical Examination: Patient appears pale and weak. Abdomen is tender upon examination with increased pain at epigastric region. Blood pressure is found to be slightly low. Assessment: Based on the presentation and reported symptoms, a working diagnosis of Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage is suspected. Plan: Immediate hospitalization is warranted given severity of symptoms and suspected diagnosis. The patient will need fluid resuscitation, supportive treatment, and diagnostic investigations including blood tests and endoscopy to confirm diagnosis and treatment plan.
9387761.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient presents with severe symptoms and a suspected diagnosis of Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage which typically requires hospital treatment including fluid resuscitation, supportive treatment, and diagnostic tests. I agree with admission.
9387761.Admission_Note_if_discharged: If discharged, the patient would be under the treatment of their primary care doctor, who could manage their condition with medication and monitoring. The patient would be advised to avoid certain foods and activities that could worsen their symptoms, they would be prescribed medication to control their symptoms and prevent further complications, and would be asked to visit the hospital for follow-up visits.

9441473.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
9441473.Admission_Note: Chief Complaint: patient presents with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. History of Present Illness: The patient has experienced progressive, severe abdominal pain over the past 24 hours, localized in the lower right quadrant of their abdomen. Accompanying symptoms are nausea, vomiting, and a loss of appetite. Past Medical History: Patient reports no notable past medical history. Physical Examination: Abdomen is tender and rigid upon palpation, particularly in the right iliac fossa. No obvious abdominal distention. Pulse 100 bpm, BP 120/80 mmHg, Temp 38.2C, RR 20/min. Assessment: Clinical presentation is most indicative of Acute Appendicitis. Plan: A CT scan is ordered to confirm diagnosis. Pending confirmation, discuss with surgical team regarding possible appendectomy. Pain management and antibiotics to be commenced for initial management.
9441473.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient is suspected to have acute appendicitis, which potentially necessitates surgical intervention and cannot be safely managed in an outpatient setting. Therefore, I agree with your decision to admit the patient for further management and potential operation.
9441473.Admission_Note_if_discharged: Given the patient's symptoms and examination findings, they are being managed for a suspected case of acute appendicitis. If they were to be discharged today, it would be necessary to ensure constant pain management at home, a course of antibiotics, and frequent check-ins with their primary care provider. The patient would need to understand that if their condition worsens, they should seek immediate emergency care. However, due to the seriousness of the suspected condition and potential for complications, such as a ruptured appendicitis, outpatient management is not the recommended course of action.

9547778.Title: Diseases of the digestive system
9547778.Admission_Note:
Chief Complaint: Severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever.

History of Present Illness: The patient complains of severe pain in the upper abdomen with shooting pain to the back. Reports consistent nausea and vomiting, with fever over the last 48 hours.

Past Medical History: Patient has a history of alcoholism and smoking, no significant surgeries in the past. No known drug allergies.

Physical Examination: Patient uncomfortable with severe tenderness in the epigastric region. Vital signs are stable but towards the higher end with a pulse of 88 bpm, BP of 140/90 mmHg, and a fever of 38.5 Celsius. Labs show increases in amylase and lipase. Ultrasound reveals inflamed pancreas.

Assessment: Tenderness, increased levels of amylase and lipase, and ultrasound results suggest acute pancreatitis.

Plan: Admission to the Gastroenterology Department for intravenous fluid replacement, fasting to rest the pancreas, pain control, and close monitoring. Alcohol and smoking cessation advised. Nutritional support will be introduced over the subsequent days as tolerated. Anticipate a 10-day hospital stay.
9547778.Admission_Note_agreement_reason: In a hospital at capacity, the decision to admit versus discharge hinges on whether a condition can be safely managed outside of the hospital setting. In this case, the patient has severe acute pancreatitis and needs admission for intravenous fluid replacement, fasting to rest the pancreas, pain control, and close monitoring. The management of this condition outside a hospital setting is risky and could lead to severe complications.
9547778.Admission_Note_if_discharged: The patient is diagnosed with acute pancreatitis, which is a severe condition that requires intensive care. If the patient were to be discharged to outpatient care, it would be for monitoring in the form of regular checkups and perhaps home health nursing. The patient would be put on a strict diet to rest the Pancreas and medications to control the pain would be prescribed. The patient would be strictly advised on lifestyle changes including alcohol and smoking cessation. However, this places the patient at a high risk of complications and isn't advisable.
